column2: Molly Carter, said Mrs. Johnson just day before yesterday, after the white-dress, Judge-Wade episode that Aunt Adeline had gone to all the friends up and down the street to be consoled about, "if you haven't got sense enough to appreciate your present blissful condition, somebody ought to operate on your mind."

column2: Now I have often told Mr. Johnson-- but here we were interrupted in what might have been the rehearsal of a glorious scrap by the appearance of Aunt Bettie Pollard, and with her came a long, tall, lovely vision of a woman in the most wonderful close clingy dress and hat that you wanted to eat the minute you saw it.
column3: Now I have often told mr Johnson- but here we were interrupted in what might have been the rehearsal of a glorious scrap by the appearance of Aunt Bettie Pollard, and with her came a long, tall, lovely vision of a woman in the most wonderful close clingy dress and hat that you wanted to eat the minute you saw it.

column2: I hated her instantly with the most intense adoration that made me want to lie down at her feet, and also made me feel as though I had gained all the more than twenty pounds that I have slaved off me and doubled them on again.
column3: I hated her instantly with the most intense adoration that made me want to lie down at her feet, and also made me feel as though I had gained all the more than twenty pounds that I have slaved off me and doubled them on again.

column3: I would have liked to lead her that minute into dr John's office and just to have looked at him and said one word-"Scarlet runner!" Aunt Betty introduced her as Miss Clinton from London.

column2: Oh, my dear Mrs. Carter, how glad I am to meet you! she said as she towered over me in a willowy way, and her voice was lovely and cool almost to slimness.
column3: Oh, my dear mrs Carter, how glad I am to meet you! she said as she towered over me in a willowy way, and her voice was lovely and cool almost to slimness.

column2: I am the bearer of so many gracious messages that I am anxious to deliver them safely to you.	I am the bearer of so many gracious messages that I am anxious to deliver them safely to you.

column2: Not six weeks ago I left Alfred Bennett in Paris, and really--really his greetings to you almost amounted to a pile of luggage.
column3: Not six weeks ago I left Alfred Bennett in Paris, and really-really his greetings to you almost amounted to a pile of luggage.

column2: He came down to Cherbourg to see me off, and almost the last thing he said to me was, 'Now, don't fail to see Mrs. Carter as soon as you get to Hillsboro; and the more you see of her the more you'll enjoy your visit to Mrs. Pollard.' Isn't he the most delightful of men?" She asked me the question, but she had the most wonderful way of seeming to be talking to everybody at one time, so Mrs. Johnson got in the first answer.

column2: Aunt Bettie had got her joining-together humour well started, and there, before my face, she made a present of every nice man in Hillsboro to that lovely, distinguished, strange girl who could have slipped through a bucket hoop if she had tried hard.
column3: Aunt Bettie had got her joining together humour well started, and there, before my face, she made a present of every nice man in Hillsboro to that lovely, distinguished, strange girl who could have slipped through a bucket hoop if she had tried hard.

column3: I had to sit there, listen to the presentations, watch her drink two delicious cups of tea full of sugar and cream, and consume without fear three of Jane's puffy cakes, while I crumbled mine in secret and set half the cup of tea out of sight behind a fern pot.

column2: It was bad enough to hear Aunt Bettie just offer her Tom, who, if he is her own son, is my favourite cousin, but I believe the worst minute I almost ever faced was when she began on the judge, for I could see from Aunt Adeline's shoulder beyond Miss Clinton how she was enjoying that, and she added another distinguished ancestor to his pedigree every time Aunt Bettie paused for breath.
column3: It was bad enough to hear Aunt Bettie just offer her Tom, who, if he is her own son, is my favourite cousin, but I believe the worst minute I almost ever faced was when she began on the judge, for I could see from Aunt Adeline's shoulder beyond Miss Clinton how she was enjoying that, and she added another distinguished ancestor to his pedigree every time Aunt Bettie paused for breath.

column3: I couldn't say a word about the fish and Aunt Adeline wouldn't!

column3: That night I did so many exercises that at last I sank exhausted in a chair in front of my mirror and put my head down on my arms and cried the real tears you cry when nobody is looking.

column3: After this I shall always appreciate and admire him for the way he made money, and his kindness in leaving it to me, since, for the first time in my life, I fully realised what it could buy.

column3: And I bought things!

column3: First I went to see Madam Courtier for corsets.

column2: I had heard about her, and I knew it meant a fortune.

column3: But that didn't matter!

column2: She came in and looked at me for about five minutes without saying a word, and then she ran her hands down and down over me until I could feel the superfluous flesh just walking off of me.
column3: She came in and looked at me for about five minutes without saying a word, and then she ran her hands down and down over me until I could feel the superfluous flesh just walking off of me.

column2: It was delicious!
column3: It was delicious!

column2: Then she and two girls wearing fashionable frocks and fashionable hair came in and did things to a corset they laced on me that I can't even write down, for I didn't understand the process, but when I looked in that long glass I almost dropped on the floor.
column3: Then she and two girls wearing fashionable frocks and fashionable hair came in and did things to a corset they laced on me that I can't even write down, for I didn't understand the process, but when I looked in that long glass I almost dropped on the floor.

column3: I wasn't tight and I wasn't stiff, and I looked-I'm too modest to write how lovely I really looked to myself.

column2: I was spellbound with delight.
column3: I was spellbound with delight.

column2: Next I signed the cheque for three of those wonders with my head so in the clouds I didn't know what I was doing, but I came to with a jolt when the prettiest girl began to get me into that black silk bag I had worn down to the West End.
column3: Next I signed the cheque for three of those wonders with my head so in the clouds I didn't know what I was doing, but I came to with a jolt when the prettiest girl began to get me into that black silk bag I had worn down to the West End.

column3: I must have shrunk the whole remaining pounds I had felt obliged to lose for Alfred and ruth Clinton, from the horror I felt when I looked at myself.

column3: The girl was really sympathetic and said with a smile that was true kindness: "Shall I call a taxi for madame and have it take her to Klein's?

column3: Of course, Klein pays Madame Courtier a commission for the customers she passes on to him. The one for me must have looked to her like a big transaction.

column3: I spent three days at the great Klein establishment, only going to the hotel to sleep, and most of the time I forgot to eat.

column3: Madame Rene must have been Madame Courtier's twin sister in youth, and Madame Telliers in the hat department was the triplet to them both.

column3: He only said politely, "And I am delighted that the trousseau is perfectly satisfactory to you, madame."

column3: The word "trousseau" can be spoken in a woman's presence for many years with no effect, but it is an awful shock when she first underscore really underscore hears it.

column2: Yes, the word "trousseau" ought to have a definite surname after it always, and that's why my loyalty dragged poor Mr. Carter out into the light of my conscience.
column3: Yes, the word "trousseau" ought to have a definite surname after it always, and that's why my loyalty dragged poor mr Carter out into the light of my conscience.

column2: The thinking of him had a strange effect on me. I had laid out the dream in dark grey-blue cloth, tailored almost beyond endurance, to wear in the train going home, and had thrown the old black silk bag across the chair to give to the hotel maid, but the decision of the session between conscience and loyalty made me pack the precious blue wonder and put on once more the black rags of remembrance in a kind of panic of respect.

column3: I would lots rather have bought poor mr Carter the monument I have been planning for months (to keep up conversation with Aunt Adeline) than wear that dress again.

column3: The next thing that happens after you have done a noble deed is, you either regard it as a reward of virtue or as a punishment for having been foolish.

column2: The judge is like that.
column3: The judge is like that.

column2: In the meantime I feel that it will be good for his judgeship for me to let him "draw" me at least a little way.
column3: In the meantime I feel that it will be good for his judgeship for me to let him "draw" me at least a little way.

column2: I may get hurt, but I shall at least have only myself to thank for it.
column3: I may get hurt, but I shall at least have only myself to thank for it.

column2: When we reached home, the judge stopped under the old lilac bush that leans over my side-gate and kissed my hand.
column3: When we reached home, the judge stopped under the old lilac bush that leans over my side gate and kissed my hand.

column2: Old Lilac shook a laugh of perfume all over us, and I believe signalled the event with the top of his bough to the white clump on the other side of the garden.
column3: Old Lilac shook a laugh of perfume all over us, and I believe signalled the event with the top of his bough to the white clump on the other side of the garden.

column2: I'm glad Aunt Adeline isn't in the flower fraternity.
column3: I'm glad Aunt Adeline isn't in the flower fraternity.

column2: Suppose she had seen or heard!
column3: Suppose she had seen or heard!

column2: And it didn't take many minutes for me to slip into old summer-before-last--also for the last time inside of those buttons--and run through the garden, my heart singing, "Billy, Billy," in a perfect rapture of tune.
column3: And it didn't take many minutes for me to slip into old summer before last-also for the last time inside of those buttons-and run through the garden, my heart singing, "Billy, Billy," in a perfect rapture of tune.

column2: I ran past the surgery door and found him in his cot almost asleep, and we had a bear reunion in the wicker chair by the window that made us both breathless.
column3: I ran past the surgery door and found him in his cot almost asleep, and we had a bear reunion in the wicker chair by the window that made us both breathless.

column2: What did you bring me, Molly? he finally kissed under my right ear.
column3: What did you bring me, Molly? he finally kissed under my right ear.

column2: A real cricket-ball and bat, lover, and an engine with five carriages, a rake and a spade and a hoe, two guns that pop a new way, and something that squirts water, and some other things.	A real cricket ball and bat, lover, and an engine with five carriages, a rake and a spade and a hoe, two guns that pop a new way, and something that squirts water, and some other things.
column3: false

column2: Will that be enough?" I hugged him up anxiously, for sometimes he is hard to please, and I might not have got the very thing he wanted.
column3: Will that be enough?" I hugged him up anxiously, for sometimes he is hard to please, and I might not have got the very thing he wanted.

column2: Thank you, Molly, all them things is what I want, but you oughter have bringed more'n that for three days not being here with me.
column3: Thank you, Molly, all them things is what I want, but you oughter have bringed more'n that for three days not being here with me.

column2: Did any woman ever have a more lovely lover than that?
column3: Did any woman ever have a more lovely lover than that?

column2: I don't know how long I should have rocked him in the twilight if Dr. John's voice hadn't come across the hall in command.
column3: I don't know how long I should have rocked him in the twilight if dr John's voice hadn't come across the hall in command.

column2: Put him down now, Mrs. Molly, and come and say other how-do-you-does, he called softly.
column3: Put him down now, mrs Molly, and come and say other how do you does, he called softly.

column2: It was a funny glad-to-see-him I felt as I came into the surgery where he was standing over by the window looking out at my garden in its twilight glow.
column3: It was a funny glad to see him I felt as I came into the surgery where he was standing over by the window looking out at my garden in its twilight glow.

column2: I gave him my hand and a good deal more of a smile and a blush than I intended.
column3: I gave him my hand and a good deal more of a smile and a blush than I intended.

column2: He very far from kissed the hand; he held it just long enough to turn me round into the light and give me one long looking-over from head to feet.
column3: He very far from kissed the hand; he held it just long enough to turn me round into the light and give me one long looking over from head to feet.

column2: Just where does that corset press you worst? he asked in the tone of voice he uses to say "put out your tongue." So much of my bad temper rose to my face that it is a wonder it didn't make a scar; but I was cold enough to all outward appearances.
column3: Just where does that corset press you worst? he asked in the tone of voice he uses to say "put out your tongue." So much of my bad temper rose to my face that it is a wonder it didn't make a scar; but I was cold enough to all outward appearances.

column2: I am making a call on a friend, Dr. Moore, and not a consultation visit to my physician, I said, looking into his face as though I had never seen him before.
column3: I am making a call on a friend, dr Moore, and not a consultation visit to my physician, I said, looking into his face as though I had never seen him before.

column2: I beg your pardon, Molly, he exclaimed, and his face was redder than mine, and then it went white with mortification.
column3: I beg your pardon, Molly, he exclaimed, and his face was redder than mine, and then it went white with mortification.

column2: I couldn't stand that.
column3: I couldn't stand that.

column2: Don't do that! I exclaimed, and before I knew it I had taken hold of his hand, and had it in both of mine.
column3: Don't do that! I exclaimed, and before I knew it I had taken hold of his hand, and had it in both of mine.

column2: I know I look as if I was shrunk or laced, but I'm not!	I know I look as if I was shrunk or laced, but I'm not!
column3: true

column2: I was going to tell you all about it.
column3: I was going to tell you all about it.

column2: I'm really inches bigger in the right place, and just--just 'controlled,' the woman called it, in the wrong place."
column3: I'm really inches bigger in the right place, and just-just 'controlled,' the woman called it, in the wrong place."

column2: The blood came back into his face, and he laughed as he gave me a little shake that pushed me away from him.
column3: The blood came back into his face, and he laughed as he gave me a little shake that pushed me away from him.

column2: Don't you ever scare me like that again, child, or it might be serious, he said in the Billy-and-me tone of voice that I like a little, only--
column3: Don't you ever scare me like that again, child, or it might be serious, he said in the Billy and me tone of voice that I like a little, only-

column2: I never will, I said in a hurry; "I want you to ask me anything in the world you want to, and I'll always do it."
column3: I never will, I said in a hurry; "I want you to ask me anything in the world you want to, and I'll always do it."

column2: Well, let me take you home through the garden then--and, yes, I believe I'll stay to supper with Mrs. Henderson.	Well, let me take you home through the garden then-and, yes, I believe I'll stay to supper with mrs Henderson.
column3: false

column2: Don't you want to tell me what a little girl like you did in a big city, and--and read me part of that Paris letter I saw the postman give Jane this afternoon?"
column3: Don't you want to tell me what a little girl like you did in a big city, and-and read me part of that Paris letter I saw the postman give Jane this afternoon?"

column2: Again I ask myself the question why his friendliness to Alfred Bennett's letters always makes me so instantly cross.
column3: Again I ask myself the question why his friendliness to Alfred Bennett's letters always makes me so instantly cross.

column2: Leaf IV.
column3: Leaf i v.

column2: Sleep is one of the most delightful and undervalued amusements known to the human race.
column3: Sleep is one of the most delightful and undervalued amusements known to the human race.

column2: I have never had enough yet, and every second of time that I'm not busy with something interesting, I curl up on the bed and go dream-hunting--only I sleep too hard to do much catching.
column3: I have never had enough yet, and every second of time that I'm not busy with something interesting, I curl up on the bed and go dream hunting-only I sleep too hard to do much catching.

column2: But this torture book found that out about me, and stopped it the very first thing on page three.
column3: But this torture book found that out about me, and stopped it the very first thing on page three.

column2: The command is to sleep as little as possible to keep the nerves in a good condition--"eight hours at the most, and seven would be better." What earthly good would a seven-hour nap do me?
column3: The command is to sleep as little as possible to keep the nerves in a good condition-"eight hours at the most, and seven would be better." What earthly good would a seven hour nap do me?

column2: I want ten hours to sleep and twelve if I get a good tired start.
column3: I want ten hours to sleep and twelve if I get a good tired start.

column2: To see me stagger out of my perfectly nice bed at six o'clock every morning now would wring the sternest heart with compassion and admiration at my faithfulness--to whom?
column3: To see me stagger out of my perfectly nice bed at six o'clock every morning now would wring the sternest heart with compassion and admiration at my faithfulness-to whom?
